document.title: Texas Essential Knowledge and Skills for Social Studies

0CF0E0C7B09346B4820A5DF8EB3016F5.description: participate in conflict resolution using persuasion, compromise, debate, and negotiation

084BF2A62B824B83B0C453AD57859088.description: use a decision-making process to identify a situation that requires a decision, gather information, identify options, predict consequences, and take action to implement a decision

7D39D1EA3EBB479FBCE6AFB6967DE703.description: use a problem-solving process to identify a problem, gather information, list and consider options, consider advantages and disadvantages, choose and implement a solution, and evaluate the effectiveness of the solution

7FC96A81AA904ECD924130A964FAAD16.description: The student uses problem-solving and decision-making skills, working independently and with others, in a variety of settings

E9384D6C0A51473E9C24D56E2A507ACB.description: create written, oral, and visual presentations of social studies information

EA68454994E0411A836156C29772A2D5.description: transfer information from one medium to another, including written to visual and written or visual to statistical, using computer software as appropriate

ED72EB61F1FD411F8EF50A72A7FA55B6.description: use standard grammar, spelling, sentence structure, and punctuation

585EA6ECD3224CB695F45344B66F7855.description: The student communicates in written, oral, and visual forms

A6C300AB60DF42ABAA1BDD5AC89DD140.description: use appropriate mathematical skills to interpret sociological information

78B06C4A4CC248C89E6C33D277E9C636.description: analyze information by sequencing, categorizing, identifying cause-and-effect relationships, comparing, contrasting, finding the main idea, summarizing, making generalizations and predictions, and drawing inferences and conclusions

AC7E0B705918412EA7DAF6DCC837E029.description: create a product on a contemporary sociological issue or topic using critical methods of inquiry

00C64C856AEC4338A60461DE9CC43FE8.description: The student applies critical-thinking skills to organize and use information acquired from a variety of valid sources, including electronic technology

771B0328D1964B54A42E645542B7D6D7.description: illustrate three social processes that contribute to social change and discuss and evaluate how technology, population, natural environment, revolution, and war cause cultures to change

5D69183C32894D899D448B7E9F5385DE.description: discuss theories that have been developed to explain collective behavior and social movements

E78A876AA803412FB1C3F8BAB2179FC2.description: compare and contrast various types of collective behavior and social movements and how they affect society

BA320D71972341478497C318AE16909E.description: The student understands how collective behavior, social movements, and modernization contribute to a changing social world

E5EE3BFFF9C64B16811E1D7187043C28.description: explain and critique various theories of population growth and its impact on society

7BFD8FE82BDC4C02AABF6763FEE7177B.description: describe the study of demography, the basic demographic concepts, and changes in settlement patterns on society

766A8F41B162489EB85B8404C0E6F9AF.description: Â The student understands how population and urbanization contribute to a changing social world

1FBF049DCB114A8F8A2D141846B2A056.description: explain the differences between the functionalist and conflict perspectives of mass media

F7F9DA558844496EBA93042D24A5BFB9.description: trace major developments in the history of mass media and identify the types of mass media in the United States

A1FF2C796D4B4F779EA4766E468A3792.description: identify factors that have contributed to the institutionalization of science, explain the norms of scientific research, and explain how these norms differ from the realities of scientific research

35B81B00A8274E2F81FEFB908AED461F.description: The student understands the basic social institutions of science and the mass media and their influence on society

CE0390C074EF427DA82777E023FF36F0.description: compare and contrast distinctive features of religion in the United States with religion in other societies

59189B43CAD1442882CAA4B262D8ECA0.description: analyze the functions of society and the basic societal needs that religion serves

3056FE589B304B6D9C1B64FB36F08766.description: examine religion from the sociological point of view

32E1BD4DDACD4E88B443478398BB173A.description: argue and defend some current issues in American education

1E8DD3C81C444C9AB23A67CC7F8F5598.description: explain functionalist, conflict, and interactionist theories of education

63D5A76E56A6485BB7FC9D23128AFA98.description: The student identifies the basic social institutions of education and religion and explains their influence on society

A24DF572FDFC41DEBC7FD83CD647AB65.description: trace the changes in ideas about citizenship and participation of different groups through time

EE5E62ED9A1C4DAEBC290FBCD2F51A5C.description: define and differentiate among different types of government and discuss the legitimacy of those in power and the impact of each on its citizens

579997A32E4D4ACEAF90260991B08C7C.description: define and differentiate between the economic models of free enterprise and socialism and how they impact society

98352DBCFC034B83B7796823026B7DF7.description: The student identifies the basic social institutions of economics and politics and explains their influence on society

512C42E3301B4A1E98F1E703DD1A3ABF.description: analyze ways in which family life can be disrupted

431CDE7E57C64A189668CBE7B69FEB7C.description: analyze the trends in American society regarding family life and the needs that the institution of family satisfies

ACBB854D3B684348A66328861453C2A9.description: define the functions and rituals of the family and how the family has changed over time

10FA9698DCC04B4F802D00830781DF10.description: The student identifies the basic social institution of the family and explains its influences on society

1EF234172B4D4BF893678D3D373ED234.description: evaluate the nature of health care in different segments of American society

5CB4834762684CB19CE5DFA2A34CACAB.description: compare the nature of health care in a global society

333BC8E2F2D4412F8A08AE43732105CF.description: analyze the effects of an aging society

40B6BA7E9EF042109AEF5765A44D2F8D.description: analyze how gender roles affect the opportunities available to men and women in society

D47B0EAA055345809921CA2B98642D17.description: The student understands changing societal views on gender, age, and health

E83FAD2841B344FC8C151E8D36370B14.description: explain instances of institutional racism in American society

9119C3CF2E8C4D8FBDF5F48C444ED138.description: analyze the varying treatment patterns of minority groups such as African American, Asian American, Hispanic American, and American Indian

BA3351B8DBC04B8C84F6CBE64215503B.description: contrast the terms discrimination, prejudice, and bias

5A55430CE17F4676B729A60F9B7F007F.description: define race and ethnicity and differentiate among the distinguishing characteristics of minority groups

CE2A25D5BB424C3BAEBF50248D8C967F.description: The student understands the impact of race and ethnicity on society

5CB9EA6092CE48CD96A08473E67542C7.description: recognize and examine global stratification and inequality

5F7FEAC6D1B44A41963921DF990CF543.description: define poverty and its components and analyze poverty's impact on the individual and society

B554B50F7B454ED28608E31395F0693D.description: analyze the characteristics and components of caste and class systems and social mobility and how motivation affects each

6C4725D019B94226BA0C5BD191C63535.description: The student understands the nature of social stratification in society

F667725660324A69909187CCEE6C9B99.description: analyze the criminal justice system in the United States in relation to deviant behavior

8ABD38D855AA41FE8BC7413C77905332.description: interpret differences in crime and arrest rates by social categories such as ethnicity, gender, socioeconomic status, and age, including cross-reference with the National Crime Victimization Survey

D55AA562E1984801A9845592E4675D8A.description: compare theories of deviance such as the functionalist, conflict, and interactionist perspectives

FE621C9079974E44822DF2CFEC2FC439.description: The student will explain the nature and social function of deviance

1EC76A0487644F44BF0DDA8207A52CDE.description: analyze the characteristics of late adulthood and changes on the individual and society such as retirement, physical and mental functioning, dependency on others, and death

E0BEF1BDE9E34D27B16FB632E9DAFEA9.description: analyze the traditional roles of work and how the composition of the labor force has changed in the United States; and

284489316E4F424C9281FD6FC41F3820.description: identify the stages of adult development and compare the differences between male and female development

E09C18EFF2274DD59BD616A36FC100D9.description: The student understands the life stage of adulthood and its characteristics

7372644912AE41A2BBC3B72623CFC568.description: identify and discuss the skills adolescents need to make responsible life choices

D424C28987AB4E39805B6AA70F076A00.description: identify issues and concerns facing contemporary adolescents such as dating, dating violence, sexuality, teen parenting, drug use, suicide, and eating disorders

05EB625813FF41C2A7E34D77E54482DD.description: identify and interpret the five characteristics of adolescence: biological growth and development, an undefined status, increased decision making, increased pressures, and the search for self

205E249055024B9597ABC19FE33232CB.description: explain how education, exclusion from the labor force, and the juvenile justice system led to the development of adolescence as a distinct stage of the life cycle

A9A5C71CDF484B2CBF5500A817A533A0.description: The student understands the concept of adolescence and its characteristics

5293202741F24320895E0EE8D117D898.description: trace socialization as a lifelong process

FCCD7FB3329249669BFEB73DD37C19B9.description: differentiate the agents of socialization and evaluate their functions and roles

16F35F477D154152ABE36379648D03C8.description: define socialization and describe how the process of socialization is culturally determined

22E3B4B9BAE54F80AC76A1FC4BB4C6A9.description: The student understands the process of socialization

7BD60107BF7D4E3EA0F21A81B36FE07A.description: examine counterculture movements and analyze their impact on society as a whole

053320D9326D43F7994950D539648376.description: analyze social problems in selected U.S. subcultures

50C408972989418FA4CA082B5D6BA75D.description: describe stereotypes of various U.S. subcultures

E24B8612C4574AFA950D0C5D7ADE5065.description: compare cultural norms such as ethnicity, national origin, age, socioeconomic status, and gender among various U.S. subculture groups

5A8C3E9F5E264ED7A478AB3C95E14D17.description: The student differentiates and recognizes examples of subculture and counterculture

B760925265544D369E34744EF540390D.description: analyze groups in terms of membership roles, status, values, mores, role conflicts, and methods of resolution

97FF1392194C4A728F299584E7C3ABD7.description: describe models of primary, secondary, formal, informal, and reference groups and e-communities

F7C89A3F024C465BAECE0DE2A72A7BB6.description: The student understands types of groups and their functions

44DF5FD86DBE4794979E80F612B8308A.description: give examples of subcultures and describe what makes them unique

DC9E5D25CB5D4D659B766F2AF2154000.description: explain how the elements of culture form a whole culture

F4C8565D6AE447DDB0F60AF143AB3675.description: identify the elements of culture to include language, symbols, norms, and values

8A4FE9EC18654884ABDA66B58897B9CC.description: analyze information about cultural life in the United States and other countries over time

51D91E0E44164F76BFF6A220F4080F8A.description: examine changes in U.S. institutions and society resulting from industrialization, urbanization, and immigrant assimilation

008BBAB1EE3E48678DA7FDADDEE61F1F.description: identify and describe the types of societies that exist in the world today

9CF0CCBF7343413592B00FAA3DFE2FEF.description: differentiate types of societies such as hunting and gathering, agrarian, pastoral, industrial, and post-industrial

5B56201D5871414CB45E9540CC0FF31D.description: The student understands how society evolves and cause and effect of social and institutional change

23D09D131E27461891D477BCA6FE44A2.description: identify sociologists such as W. E. B. DuBois, Booker T. Washington, Robert E. Park, Harriet Martineau, Jane Addams, Robert Nisbet, and Julian Samora and interpret their contributions to the field

9B6A2CB1249A4E53B82C8538563B7CF1.description: identify leading sociologists in the field of social science, including Auguste Comte, Emile Durkheim, Herbert Spencer, Max Weber, and Karl Marx, and interpret their contributions to the foundation of sociology

C48BE7E9468943C3AA4FBF743362B885.description: describe the development of the field of sociology

9C0244EA0A764FEB87B77207A7BDE345.description: The student understands the theoretical perspectives of the historical interpretations of human social development
